row.Text: For the current status, all private betas are hidden (in the sense that our direct UI will not show associations and the like) during this period, this site isn't special in that matter. So it's not a propogation issue.
Also figured that was a possibility, but I'd not done a SE private beta before, so I wasn't sure. I've edited that piece out to focus on the current/future plans.
I'm sure it won't be an issue at all, since people will check the checkbox even if they are under 18 =P But still, I'm hoping it will be removed in the future
If a separate account is created, will there be a way to "mark as non-merge" as I expect they will be shown as coming from the same IP in the mod tools?

I have to respectfully disagree with this stance. I personally don't care if people stumble onto the fact that I'm on sexuality.SE, but I can see it being a problem for others who don't want to be managing a bunch of IDs but also don't want this showing up on their public profile. A network-wide "Do not show" flag on accounts seems like a reasonable request to me, even if the only use case winds up being sexuality.SE
@voretaq7: Make it a feature request. The argument sounds like something reasonable to consider.

Pornography is hard to define, but I'll know it when I see it! - Hon. Potter Stewart, Associate Justice - US Supreme Court ; roughly paraphrased. (It's worth noting the irony that Justice Stewart was actually ruling that something *wasn't* pornographic when he wrote those famous words)

[Consider it done!](http://meta.sexuality.stackexchange.com/questions/8/account-flag-do-not-show-in-my-stack-exchange-profile) I put it up here for now to see what the rest of the Sexuality beta users think -- If it looks sound we can migrate it to mSO for a broader audience.
This would be implemented as a "do not associate" setting... just to clarify the terminology.
Note that I already closed this as clearly off-topic, both by the description and name of the site *and* the example questions of the Definition phase.
ok, thanks. Yea, I noticed shortly after I posted this question it became closed.

Still, your point stands: pornography is defined by "community norms" in the United States. Given that communities in, say, rural areas are going to define graphic content differently than, say, suburban and/or urban areas will, well. Safe than sorry. :D
People are going to be doing it whether they're legally allowed or not, and if they're going to be doing it, I'd much prefer to see them asking questions about it.

This is a very important question. I feel that we need to strive to make all feel comfortable on this site, and if we make certain assumptions about "normal" we may inadvertently exclude some. This is something we need to be very conscious about.

Sexuality is a tricky thing when we make assumptions (the most common assumption: Pronouns indicating both birth gender and gender identity, and that birth gender and gender identity are the same). This is an excellent question to help us sort out the kind of guidance we want to give to people asking questions.

Agreed. We should not be giving medical advice (at least not anything beyond "You should talk to your doctor about..."), but I can't imagine a site about sex and sexuality that doesn't tread into the medical from time to time.

Possibly related question on main: [What are the medical benefits and drawbacks of circumcision?](http://sexuality.stackexchange.com/questions/22/what-are-the-medical-benefits-and-drawback-of-circumcision)
I suspect we'll spend a lot of time editing questions to clarify their context, or at least commenting to gather more information from the OP. That, or answers will have lots of clauses.

From my experience over on ServerFault we'll always have a mix of askers: Those (unfortunately few) who are very specific and give us enough information to formulate a good answer, and the (unfortunately larger) group where we have to coax out enough information to help them. A good FAQ and some asking prompts will help somewhat, as will an active presence in chat for those that can spend time there.
A permanent synonym from sodomy (and maybe other terms like buggery which I think is a pretty common British variant) would probably help keep the tag list clean.

@RobertCartaino I think you're safe posting that as an answer -- The very definition of the site on Area51 (***Human*** *Sexuality*) puts it out of bounds. In fact we may want to change our title accordingly -- I'll post a separate discussion Q. for that.
I threw a [tag:faq-topics] tag on this -- a mod may want to convert that to plain [tag:faq]. Like I said in my answer below I expect this will be a FAQ (and should be in *the* FAQ)...
This or Roberts suggestion of [tag:sexual-technique] seems to make the most sense. I'll retag later today to use whichever has managed to climb to the top of the vote charts :)
This or Hobblin's suggestion of [tag:sexual-practice] seems to make the most sense. I'll retag later today to use whichever has managed to climb to the top of the vote charts :)

rpg.SE is a good example (I'm actually not sure what could be more contentious, sexual advice or picking a gaming system for a tabletop group!) -- There's also a lesser precedent within the trilogy sites, or at least on SF and SO ("Best Practices" type questions)
Especially because sodomy and anal sex are not exact synonyms.
@GraceNote I've noticed it has started to appear on my other account pages. Is this a change in the system?
Gotta say I disagree with your first point there. Asexuality is a thing we should be respectful of here.
@Abby: I think that's a really good point; given most people won't know the difference, it's better to keep to better-understood terms.

Such a feature would also be really useful for us beta participants, who needed to use their main account to be able to get into the site at all, but might prefer to keep it separate from their other SE accounts. Particularly as those other accounts may be linked (as mine is) to their professional identity.
Er, do you mean tag synonyms? That's a possibility; the community would have to agree, though.
@AbbyT.Miller Dr. Freud's point, not mine :) -- Your point is well taken though, and I agree that asexuality is also a valid sexual expression and definitely has a place on this site.

This conveys the same point I was trying to make much more clearly. If there are relevant aspects of a question it should be included in the question, either by explicitly stating "These are my assumptions" or (preferably) making the question clear enough that such a statement isn't necessary.

I do *not* think we should accept speculative answers. This site's purpose is to appeal to professional and academic-level sex therapists and researchers. Questions in which amateurs and untrained enthusiasts speculate as to causation or correlation will not bring those people here.
I agree completely.
Yes, sadly, even "normal" is subjective. ***When in doubt, ask more information...***
Indeed, we have to watch out for tags like [sex], [sexual], [sexuality], [human-sexuality]; they simply barely add meaning as our site is about all that anyway. Well spotted! :)

+1 I love this [Jeopardy](http://blog.stackoverflow.com/2011/07/its-ok-to-ask-and-answer-your-own-questions/) answer; funny how you go dumb down advice questions and then self answer your question to promote them! Besides knowledge having advice is very valuable, but we should indeed caution for those exception where it can be hazardous to the individual if it isn't handled in a medical context...
Indeed, as Robert mentions. This should get rid of the association, such that it also doesn't show up under "other accounts" too. As for now, changing your profile a bit is the best option available.

It looks like [tag:sexual-practice] and [tag:sexual-technique] are tied - I'm accepting [tag:sexual-practice] & retagging my question because it seems to fit best. [tag:sexual-technique] is probably a good fit for questions about the "mechanical" aspects (insert tab A into slot B as it were :)

I think a lot of questions here will have answers that come with caveats, even "nonmedical" ones (cf. my ["BIG IMPORTANT DISCLAIMER"](http://sexuality.stackexchange.com/questions/31/warming-a-tenga-masturbator)])
…Also I really wanted a good example of an advice question but my brain stubbornly refused to give me one at 3 AM :P

I think the Sexuality community is pretty much agreed that this is a good idea (I *really* didn't expect this to be the highest voted Meta question! Dang!) -- @RobertCartaino should we move this to meta.SO, or can you prod some of the developers for us from here? :)
Our FAQ should definitely mention the "human" part either way
+1 for a synonym (Orgasm should probably be the main tag: as Tom notes it's the term that seems most associated with sexuality)
@voretaq7: It has sufficient attention here. It does not need to be moved.
I agree with the conclusion that sexuality fits while society does not.
I've commented as much about sodomy; in many legal contexts it's not restricted to *just* anal sex but oral sex as well.
Hopefully the [LGBT proposal](http://area51.stackexchange.com/proposals/13507/lgbt) will be able to fill the rest of the niche soon.
Just a note (plug) to encourage people interested in discussing gender-related issues to follow the [LGBT proposal](http://area51.stackexchange.com/proposals/13507/lgbt) so we can get it made!
@Aarthi: yes, I mean synonyms, thanks! Confused my terminology. I'll update the answer now.
" Links to external content rarely constitutes a good answer, anyway." Really!? I frequently link to sources to back up my answers or show what research I've already done in questions.
I think I like this answer the most. If it's speculation that can be backed up with hard evidence, that's ok. But otherwise, we shouldn't allow it.
If a man cuts off a woman's nipple with a chainsaw, that's PG-13. But kiss it, and it's R.
`sexuality` was automatically a banned tag (per it being the domain name). I've added `sex` to that as well.
I fail to see any significant difference between 2 and 3 except that 3 can relate to practices done in a non-sexual context.
@Hobblin: That's why I included the two, just for that distinction :)
Which questions are you referring to specifically?
I agree completely - these questions are on topic, but we need to be careful about being as professional, academic, and research-based as possible.

+1 for Kainaw's criterion. I think that should be applied here. We can deal with "can be answered partly by diagnosis/prognosis/treatment advice and partly by some other type of information" on a case by case basis. But bottom line: this is not a medical site. And a site full of questions whose only answers are "talk to your doctor" help no one.

@MattChan Here's one: http://sexuality.stackexchange.com/questions/81/how-much-masturbation-is-too-much and another http://sexuality.stackexchange.com/questions/10/how-to-deal-with-erectile-disfunction
While I certainly feel that sex related questions can be very romantically inclined, I do feel that it might be misleading to newer users. +1 in favor of scrapping.
+1 because I agree. But since I do think we do want to attract experts, I also feel it is worth discussing, especially as we shape the site. This is where my vote stands on the issue though.

Agreed that trigger warnings would be a valuable part of e site, and something I think we need if we want to be a useful resource for people of all experiences. Spoiler tags are probably the best we currently have, and I like them because they actively block out the text so people don't have to see them if they may be triggered by the text.

@me_and I'm pretty sure that what Robert meant is answers that are *only* or *primarily* links to external sites make poor answers. We always encourage users to have multiple references to back up their claims, but to summarize the relevant content from the link so that you get a complete answer just by looking at the page on this site where the question is.

It would seem that american culture has perverted the use of the word "fetish" but since the actual meaning of the word is very much different from the "kink" I think it would be a really bad idea to make them "more-or-less synonyms"
+1 as this covers my opinion pretty damn well. I do think it's a useful discussion to have explicitly, though.

This articulates my qualm with removing 'romantic' entirely pretty well (I was having trouble getting the words out before). I'm not sure what the solution is, but I agree that that intent needs to remain in the FAQ.

The downside of this is that if the core of a question is something deserving of a warning, then the answers probably will be too, and basically everything has to be hidden, which is awkward for people trying to read it. Of course, if the choice is between protecting people and ease of reading, we must protect people, but maybe we can come up with something better.

Following the shut down, the site's data will be available for download. See the [Game of Go](http://area51.stackexchange.com/proposals/11942/game-of-go) proposal for an example. Also, see the [3D Graphics](http://area51.stackexchange.com/proposals/5022/3d-graphics) proposal for an example of what happens when we kick a site back to Area 51.

Also, I'd like to point out that [Mathematica](http://area51.stackexchange.com/proposals/37304/mathematica) had its proposal closed, re-proposed, and surged to become one of our *fastest and most successful launch proposals* to date. This is ***not*** a punishment; it is a measure to make sure the site can and will succeed in a healthy way.

These sites all derive from the programming Q&A site stackoverflow.com, where there is a definitive answer for every question that can easily be substantiated with evidence from technical documentations and repeatable test cases. With topics like these, there often AREN'T scientific studies to lean on—or if there are, they are the privileged knowledge of academia; the majority of people are just going to use Wikipedia. So I think demands may have been unreasonable as it was trying to pigeonhole the idea into too strict a format.

@HughGuiney: The idea that Stack Exchange only works with "one definitive answer" subjects **was debunked ages ago.** http://blog.stackoverflow.com/2010/09/good-subjective-bad-subjective/ should be *required* reading for this site.
It is very unfortunate as I found your answers to be informative. If I wanted to read wikpedia, I would be going to wikipedia anyway.
